  • Active-Brownian Dynamics

Active-Brownian Dynamics¶

Consider a particle undergoing random motion over a potential \(V\). For our development, we focus on 1-dimensional transport, but the final results are extended to 3 dimensions. The particle is subjected to thermal (emph{i.e.} Brownian) force \(f_{B}\) and active forces \(f_{A}\) that represent transient perturbations from the surrounding enzyme activity. The temporal evolution of the position \(x(t)\) is governed by a modified Langevin equation

(1)¶\[\xi \frac{d x}{d t} = f_{V} + f_{B} + f_{A},\]

where \(f_{V} = - \frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\) is the potential force on the particle at position \(x\).

The Brownian force \(f_{B}\) is governed by the fluctuation dissipation theorem, which states that \(f_{B}\) is a Gaussian-distributed random force that satisfies

\[\begin{split}\langle f_{B}(t) \rangle & = & 0, \\ \langle f_{B}(t) f_{B}(t') \rangle & = & \kappa^{(B)} ( |t - t'|) = 2 k_{B}T \xi \delta (t - t').\end{split}\]

This assumes that the environment is purely Newtonian, leading to the instantaneous decorrelation of Brownian forces (i.e. Gaussian white noise). Diffusive transport in a viscoelastic fluid leads to temporal memory in the Brownian force, reflecting temporal correlation in the frictional stress. Our approach is amenable to address such physics, and we develop this in the appendix to this paper.

In our work, we assume the active force \(f_{A}\) are also Gaussian-distributed with an arbitrary temporal correlation, such that

\[\begin{split}\langle f_{A}(t) \rangle & = & 0, \\ \langle f_{A}(t) f_{A}(t') \rangle & = & \kappa^{(A)}(|t-t'|),\end{split}\]

where \(\kappa^{(A)}(t)\) represents the temporal correlation between active forces.

This theoretical model results in a Smoluchowski equation (or Schr"{o}dinger equation) that is given by

(2)¶\[\begin{split}\frac{\partial G(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{0}; t)} {\partial t} & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\xi} \nabla^{2} G(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{0}; t) - \frac{1}{\xi} \vec{\nabla} \cdot \left[ \vec{f}_{V} G(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{0}; t) \right] \\ & & + \frac{1}{2 \xi^{2}} \int_{0}^{t} dt_{1} \int d \vec{r}_{1} K_{A}^{-1}(t-t_{1}) \left[ \vec{\nabla}_{r} G(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{1}; t- t_{1}) \right] \cdot \left[ \vec{\nabla}_{r_{1}} G(\vec{r}_{1}|\vec{r}_{0}; t_{1}) \right],\end{split}\]

which is composed of the thermal and active contributions.

The active-Brownian Smoluchowski equation (Eq. (2)) defines the conditions for the steady-state probability distribution \(p_{ss}(\vec{r})\). Upon Laplace transform of Eq. (2) and applying Final Value Theorem, we arrive at the condition

(3)¶\[0 = H_{0} p_{ss}(\vec{r}) + \frac{1}{2 \xi^{2}} \int d \vec{r}_{1} \left[ \vec{\nabla}_{r} \tilde{G}_{A}(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{1}) \right] \cdot \left[ \vec{\nabla}_{r_{1}} p_{ss} (\vec{r}_{1}) \right],\]

where \(H_{0} p_{ss}(\vec{r})\) is the standard Smoluchowski operator

\[H_{0} p_{ss}(\vec{r}) = \frac{k_{B}T}{\xi} \nabla^{2} p_{ss}(\vec{r}) - \frac{1}{\xi} \vec{\nabla} \cdot \left[ \vec{f}_{V} p_{ss}(\vec{r}) \right]\]

and \(\tilde{G}_{A}\) is defined as

\[\tilde{G}_{A}(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{1}) = \int_{0}^{\infty} \! \! dt K_{A}^{-1}(t) G(\vec{r}|\vec{r}_{1};t).\]

The steady-state condition \(p_{ss}\) requires evaluation of Eq. (2), which implies the non-equilibrium nature of the active-Brownian particle.

Our current development is a generalized representation of an active-Brownian particle. However, the active-force correlation function \(K_{A}^{-1}\) defines a time-scale of communication of active forces

\[t_{A} = \frac{\int_{0}^{\infty} d t K_{A}^{-1}(t) t }{\int_{0}^{\infty} d t K_{A}^{-1}(t)}\]

As this time scale approaches zero, the active-force correlation can be written as \(K_{A}^{-1}(t) = 2 \xi k_{B} T_{A} \delta (t)\), where we define an active temperature \(T_{A}\). This limit implies the effect of active forces can be interpreted as an effective active-Brownian temperature \(T_{AB} = T + T_{A}\).

However, the time scale of relaxation of the particle in the absence of active forces defines whether the active forces perturb the behavior beyond this effective temperature. This is particularly true for a system with a spectrum of relaxation time scales, where some relaxation processes are faster than the active-force correlation time \(t_{A}\). Such effects are prevalent for the dynamics of a polymer chain subjected to both active and Brownian fluctuations.

Dynamic behavior of an Active-Brownian polymer¶

We apply our results of an active-Brownian particle in a harmonic potential to the problem of an active-Brownian polymer chain. Since the normal-mode expansion of the Rouse polymer adopts the form of a particle in a harmonic potential, we can frame our results in the previous section to find the behavior of the pth normal mode.

The mapping from the harmonic particle to the pth normal mode involves replacing the following variables: \(\xi \rightarrow N \xi\), \(k \rightarrow k_{p} = \frac{3 \pi^{2} k_{B}T}{b^{2} N} p^{2}\), \(f_{A}^{2} \rightarrow N f_{A}^{2}\). We then define the Rouse time \(t_{R} = N^{2} b^{2} \xi /(3 \pi^{2} k_{B}T)\) as the longest internal relaxation time of the polymer, emph{i.e.} \(t_{R} = N\xi/k_{1}\) for the \(p=1\) normal mode.

We defined the normal-mode correlation function for the pth mode to be

\[C_{p}(\tau) = \langle \vec{X}_{p}(\tau) \cdot \vec{X}_{p'} (0) \rangle = \frac{3 k_{B}T}{k_{p}} \left[ 1 + \frac{F_{A}^{2}}{2} \frac{K_{A}}{K_{A}+p^{2}} \right] \exp \left( - p^{2} \tau \right) \delta_{pp'}\]

where \(F_{A}^{2} = f_{A}^{2}/(k_{A} \xi k_{B}T)\) and \(K_{A} = t_{R} k_{A} = N^{2} b^{2} \xi k_{A} /(3 \pi^{2} k_{B}T)\). The dimensionless time \(\tau = t/t_{R}\) is scaled by the Rouse time of the polymer.

We find the center-of-mass mean-square displacement to be

(4)¶\[\mathrm{MSD}_{\mathrm{com}} = \langle \left( \vec{X}_{0}(t) - \vec{X}_{0}(0) \right)^{2} \rangle = \frac{k_{B} T}{k_{1}} \left\{ 6 \tau + 3 F_{A}^{2} \left[ \tau - \frac{1}{K_{A}} + \frac{1}{K_{A}} \exp \left( - K_{A} \tau \right) \right] \right\}.\]

We note that Eq. (4) has the short-time asymptotic behavior \(\mathrm{MSD}_{\mathrm{com}} \rightarrow 6 [k_{B}T/(\xi N)] t \), which coincides with the mean-square displacement for a Brownian-only polymer. The long-time asymptotic behavior \(\mathrm{MSD}_{\mathrm{com}} \rightarrow 6 [k_{B}T/(\xi N)] (1 + F_{A}^{2}/2) t \) reveals the long-time effective temperature due to Brownian and active fluctuations, given by \(T_{AB} = T (1 + F_{A}^{2}/2)\).

The mean-square displacement of a segment of the polymer chain is define as

(5)¶\[\mathrm{MSD} = \langle \left( \vec{r}(n, t) - \vec{r}(n, 0) \right)^{2} \rangle\]

for the \(n\). In this work, we focus on the midpoint motion at \(n=N/2\), but this is easily extended to other polymer positions. We insert our normal-mode representation into Eq. (5), resulting in the expression

\[\begin{split}\mathrm{MSD} & = & \sum_{p=0}^{\infty} \sum_{p'=0}^{\infty} \langle \left( \vec{X}_{p}(t) - \vec{X}_{p}(0) \right) \cdot \left( \vec{X}_{p'}(t) - \vec{X}_{p'}(0) \right) \rangle \phi_{p}(n=N/2) \phi_{p'}(n=N/2) \nonumber \\ & = & \mathrm{MSD}_{\mathrm{com}} + \sum_{p = 1}^{\infty} 12 \frac{k_{B}T}{k_{2p}} \left[ 1 + \frac{F_{A}^{2}}{2} \frac{K_{A}}{K_{A}+(2p)^{2}} \right] \left[ 1 - \exp \! \left( - \frac{k_{2p}}{N \xi} t \right) \right].\end{split}\]

In addition, we define the the mean-square change in distance (MSCD) for a polymer chain. This quantity is defined as

\[\mathrm{MSCD} = \langle \left( \Delta \vec{R}(t) - \Delta \vec{R}(0) \right)^{2} \rangle\]

where \(\Delta \vec{R}(t) = \vec{r}(N/2 + \Delta, t) - \vec{r}(N/2 - \Delta,t)\). Thus, MSCD is a measure of the change in separation distance between two points on the polymer that are \(2 \Delta\) segments from each other. This results in the expression

\[\mathrm{MSCD} = \sum_{p = 0}^{\infty} 48 \frac{k_{B}T}{k_{2p+1}} \left[ 1 + \frac{F_{A}^{2}}{2} \frac{K_{A}}{K_{A}+(2p+1)^{2}} \right] \left[ 1 - \exp \! \left( - \frac{k_{2p+1}}{N \xi} t \right) \right] \sin^{2} \left[ \frac{\pi (2p+1) \Delta}{N} \right]\]

Functions contained with the ‘active_brown’ module¶

Active-Brownian dynamics

Notes

Detailed derivations for MSD and MSCD are found in “Interplay of active and thermal fluctuations in polymer dynamics”

wlcstat.active_brown.mscd_active(t, D, ka, fa, Ndel, N, b=1, num_modes=20000)[source]¶

Compute mscd for two points on an active-Brownian polymer.

Parameters

  • t ((M,) float, array_like) – Times at which to evaluate the MSCD

  • D (float) – Diffusion coefficient, (in desired output length units). Equal to \(k_BT/\xi\) for \(\xi\) in units of “per Kuhn length”.

  • ka (float) – Dimensionless active-force rate constant

  • fa (float) – Dimensionless active-force magnitude

  • Ndel (float) – Distance from the last linkage site to the measured site. This ends up being (1/2)*separation between the loci (in Kuhn lengths).

  • N (float) – The full length of the linear polymer (in Kuhn lengths).

  • b (float) – The Kuhn length (in desired length units).

  • num_modes (int) – how many Rouse modes to include in the sum

Returns

mscd – result

Return type

(M,) np.array<float>

wlcstat.active_brown.msd_active(t, D, ka, fa, N, b=1, num_modes=20000)[source]¶

Compute msd for two points on an active-Brownian polymer.

Parameters

  • t ((M,) float, array_like) – Times at which to evaluate the MSCD

  • D (float) – Diffusion coefficient, (in desired output length units). Equal to \(k_BT/\xi\) for \(\xi\) in units of “per Kuhn length”.

  • ka (float) – Dimensionless active-force rate constant

  • fa (float) – Dimensionless active-force magnitude

  • N (float) – The full length of the linear polymer (in Kuhn lengths).

  • b (float) – The Kuhn length (in desired length units).

  • num_modes (int) – how many Rouse modes to include in the sum

Returns

msd – result

Return type

(M,) np.array<float>

Example usage of ‘msd_active’¶

We show the solution for the MSD for chain length \(N=100\) for an active-Brownian polymer. The top and middle plots show the behavior for \(K_{A} = 10\) with varying \(F_{A}^{2}\), and the bottom plot shows the behavior for \(F_{A}^{2} = 100\) with varying \(K_{A}\). The long-time asymptotic behavior for the active-Brownian polymer (dashed) is given by the long-time behavior of the center-of-mass MSD, which is given by \(\mathrm{MSD}_{\mathrm{com}} \rightarrow 6 [k_{B}T/(\xi N)] (1 + F_{A}^{2}/2) t\).

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)

Example usage of ‘mscd_active’¶

We show the solution for the MSCD for chain length \(N=100\) and \(\Delta = 25\) for an active-Brownian polymer. The top plot shows the behavior for \(K_{A} = 10\) with varying \(F_{A}^{2}\), and the bottom plot shows the behavior for \(F_{A}^{2} = 100\) with varying \(K_{A}\). The long-time asymptotic behavior for the Brownian-only polymer is found by noting

\[\mathrm{MSCD} = \langle \left( \Delta \vec{R}(t) - \Delta \vec{R}(0) \right)^{2} \rangle = \langle \Delta \vec{R}(t)^{2} \rangle - 2 \langle \Delta \vec{R}(t) \cdot \Delta \vec{R}(0) \rangle + \langle \Delta \vec{R}(0) ^{2} \rangle \rightarrow 2 \langle \Delta \vec{R}^{2} \rangle\]

which leads to the asymptotic solutions

\[\mathrm{MSCD} \rightarrow 4 \Delta\]

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)

(Source code, png, hires.png, pdf)
